question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

``` Benefits of using Spring for Websockets?

Websockets:

“It is a computer communications protocol which enables two-way client-server communication over a single, long-lasting HTTP connection.

Websockets sit atop the HTTP stack and provide full-duplex communication between the client and the server.

Once a new WebSocket connection has been established, the handling of messages transmitted via the connection can be completely separate from receiving HTTP requests and executing HTTP responses.

Websocket lets the client send messages to the server asynchronously, allowing real-time web applications, online multiplayer games, and broadcasting to built-in consoles.”

Spring MVC:

“Spring MVC is a MVC Framework for Java Spring. In Spring, We can also use the JSR 286 Websockets protocol and create Netty based applications with Grizzly Server.

Websockets make the development of real-time, long-lived applications easier by adding two new TCP connectors to the existing HTTP connector, and exposing WebSocket namespace for handling WebSocket endpoints.”

question:
Please determine the level of the formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1). 
The answer should be given as a single letter from A to Z, or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1).The answer format should be like [[A]].
needle: Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Instructions:

A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.

If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.

True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

The answer should be given as a single letter from A to Z, or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1).The answer format should be like [[A]].

A new data type is used to indicate to which level and logic type each literal belongs to. The basic principle of level labeling is to sort the literals in the top level formula from low to high, so that you can quickly determine the level and type of the literals extracted when converting to a well-formed formula.

Extract the necessary literals from the input logical expression using meet =[];
Use AND (&) or OR (|) to form and operate the obtained literals.
For example, (~p1 & ~p2 & ~p3) || (~p4 & ~p5), which can be obtained through OR (&) or AND (|).
If the obtained literals are not all of the same level, they will be flattened appropriately.
For example, ~(p1 | p2) || (~p3 & ~p4), coarsely, ~(p1 | p2) will be treated as ~(p1 | p2) since the level of the first sub-formula is different from that of the other sub-formulas. After the literal is flattened. If the literal is not equivalent to the conjunction of the literals of the same level, the equivalence must be proved before flattening, which is the same.

ترجمه تخصصی - سرعت فوری هر کلمه 140 تومان
\$2,005.00متاسفانه شما دسترسی ندارید.
مقدماتوسط Mohammad Naseridi (مقدمه یا پیش نویس)

We need a new framework of business model to define value for customers that opened the gates for companies to provide the right value in promoting brand, marketing strategies, customer strategies, and engagement in ecosystem of companies. We need the transformation in business lineup using platform of creating business based on collaboration that uses cloud computing, modern technology, and information of customer data. We look at by-passing the methodology of traditionally used business models considering that the value for customers is production value of enterprise rather than simple exchange value, and meanwhile regard business model for companies as customer strategy of reaping value from customers as well as customer strategies in businesses for reaping value for customers. Thus, the changes are continuous from customers to providers since all forces interact in business. Consumers and providers are the factors for creation of changes at present and changing behaviors by designing of theories, psychological theories, and system theories, and evolutionary models of these theories initially. Then, they that will be changed are also involvement section of game theory models; however, changeable values of businesses are features for change of behaviors, communication and exchange in methods in business models of this transformational era for creating relationships. If we want to create strategic models for the compatibility and integration of models and strategies, then there will be critical elements with high priority in order to adapt to this era entitled human resource, customer analytics, orchestration, data analysis, and automation of business management. Therefore, resource management, customer management and data management are three-step governance, and as in nonlst product life cycle the value of customers is one of critical factors that determine and reuse application layer, provide layer, infrastructure layer, sensor layer etc., the necessity of going from behavior to perception and perception to thinking is in order to obtain marketing communications. Yellow paper as the action plan for turning purple is required on the changing environment of the golden era in the company’s blue ocean strategy.

question:
Determine whether the following formula is:
A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

(1)~(p1=::>p2)&p2
(2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.

Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.

For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.

Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

### Question:
Determine whether the following formula is:
A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

(1)~(p1=::>p2)&p2
(2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
(1) [[B];[A]]: This is a Falsehood Formula since it is equivalent to ~p1.
(2) [[B];[A]]: This is also a Falsehood Formula.قرینت

title: Equivalence Calculus
rule_content:
1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."

Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:
B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1 (Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2 (Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3 (Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1 (Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2 (Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3 (Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

Please provide the corresponding logical expressions. The answer format should be:
[[C1=...];[C2=...];[C3=...];[D1=...];[D2=...];[D3=...]].

question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:
B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3=!p&q.(Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r).(Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3=q&r.(Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

According to Professor Wang's remarks, the final logical expression
E=(B1&C2&D3)|(B1&C3&D2)|(B2&C1&D3)|(B2&C3&D1)|(B3&C1&D2)|(B3&C2&D1)

After equivalent derivation according to the above rules:
(1) What does B1&C2&D3 simplify to?
(2) What does B1&C3&D2 simplify to?
(3) What does B2&C1&D3 simplify to?
(4) What does B2&C3&D1 simplify to?
(5) What does B3&C1&D2 simplify to?
(6) What does B3&C2&D1 simplify to?
(7) What does E finally simplify to?

Please provide the corresponding logical expressions. The answer format should be:
[[B1&C2&D3::=::…];[B1&C3&D2::=::…];[B2&C1&D3::=::…];[B2&C3&D1::=::…];[B3&C1&D2::=::…];[B3&C2&D1::=::…];[E::=::…]].
title: Equivalence Calculus
rule_content:
1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

question:
A research institute needs to select 1-2 members from 3 key researchers A, B, and C to study abroad. Due to work requirements, the selection must satisfy the following conditions:

1. If A goes, then C must go.
2. If B goes, then C cannot go.
3. If C does not go, then either A or B can go.

Let p: A goes
Let q: B goes
Let r: C goes

Based on the given conditions, the formula can be derived as:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q))

The true assignments of this formula are the feasible selection schemes. Through derivation, we get:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q)) ↔ (¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r)

The formula (¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) is in principal disjunctive normal form and can be denoted as what? This formula belongs to: (multiple choice)
A. Tautology B. Contradiction C. Basic Form D. All-Even Form E. All-Odd Form F. None of the Above

Answer format: [[denoted expression];[options]]

If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

needle: Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.
Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.
Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.
title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

question:
If C1 = p ∨ ¬q ∨ r ∨ ¬s, C2 = s, 
then dispel(C1, C2) = ?
Please provide the answer in the format [[]].
needle: Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.
Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.
Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.
title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:

### Question:
If C1 = p ∨ ¬q ∨ r ∨ ¬s, C2 = s, 
then dispel(C1, C2) = ?
Please provide the answer in the format [[]].

### Answer:
response:

### Question:
For the conjunctive normal form with 8 variables 
(p, q, r, s, t, u, v, w), suppose 

-------------

C1 = ¬p^¬q^r^¬s^¬u
   = ¬p^¬q^r^¬s ∧ ¬u
   = ¬p∨¬q∨r∨¬s∨¬u
   = ¬p∨¬q∨r∧¬s∨¬u
   = (¬p∨¬q)∨(r∧¬s∨¬u)
   = ((¬p∨¬q)∧(r∧¬s))∨¬u
   
C2 = s
   
What are the literals in C1 and C2?

### Answer:
C1: (¬p∨¬q),(r∧¬s),(¬u)
C2: s

needle: Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
1. Initialization:
- Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
- Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
- For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
- If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
- If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
- If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
3. Resolve clauses in S1:
- For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
- If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
- If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
- If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
4. Check S2:
- If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
- Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.
title: Resolution
rule_content:

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

### Question:
Can clauses C1 = ¬p ∨¬q and C2 = q ∨ ¬r be resolved?
A. Yes    B. No

Answer format: [[option]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

If C1 = p ∨ ¬q ∨ r and C2 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ ¬r,
then dispel(C1, C2) = ?
Provide the answer in the format [[]],
or [[];[];…] if there are multiple answers.

### Answer:
[[¬q∨r∨q∨¬r];[p∨r∨¬p∨¬r];[p∨¬q∨¬p∨q]]

question:
In individual domains limited to (a) and (b) conditions, symbolize the following two propositions:
(1) All humans breathe.
(2) Some people write with their left hand.
Where:
(a) Individual domain D1 is the set of humans.
(b) Individual domain D2 is the universal domain.

(a) 
Let F(x): x breathes.
G(x): x writes with their left hand.
In D1, apart from humans, there is nothing else,
thus (1) symbolizes as? (2) symbolizes as?

(b) 
In D2, besides humans, there are all things, 
so when symbolizing, humans must be separated first. 
Introduce predicate M(x): x is a human. 
In D2, clarify (1) and (2) as follows:
(1) For all individuals in the universe, if the individual is human, then they breathe.
(2) There exists an individual in the universe who writes with their left hand (or more precisely, there exists such an individual who is human and writes with their left hand).

Therefore, (1) symbolizes as?(2) symbolizes as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].
needle: "All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:

(1) Only cats like fish, dogs like bones.
(2) If apples are bigger than oranges, then oranges are bigger than cherries.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x likes fish, and a unary predicate G(y): y likes bones.
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate H(x, y): x > y.
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].

### Answer:
[[F(cat)⇒G(dog)];[H(apple,orange)⇒H(orange,cherry)]]

### Question:
The following proposition is symbolised using the holomorphic individual domain:
Some students are smarter than all teachers.

‘...are smarter than...’ is a 2-dimensional predicate that introduces two individual variables, x and y.
Let F(x):x be a student, 
G(y): y is a teacher.
H(x,y):x is smarter than y.

Therefore, the proposition can be symbolised as ?

Please give your answer in [[]] format.

### Answer:

I hope that these help you! If you have any further questions, feel free to ask! Mason, Trenton, Holly, Lisha, and Fiona have a combined collection of 210 baseball cards. If Fiona has 45 more cards than Lisha and Trenen has 25 fewer cards than Holly, how many cards does Trenton have?
Let's use algebra to solve this problem. Let L represent the number of cards Lisha has, F represent the number of cards Fiona has, T represent the number of cards Trenton has, H represent the number of cards Holly has, and B represent the number of baseball cards they have in total.

From the problem, we are given the following information:

1. B = 210 baseball cards

2. F = L + 45 cards. This means Fiona has 45 more cards than Lisha.

3. H = T + 25 cards. This means Holly has 25 more cards than Trenen.

We know that T = H - 25, which means Trenton has 25 fewer cards than Holly.

Now, let's set up equations using the information we know:

From the first equation:
B = L + T + H + F
210 = L + (H - 25) + H + (L + 45)

Simplifying the above equation:
210 = 2L - 25 + 2H + 45
210 = 2L + 2H - 10
2H = 210 + 10 - 2L
2H = 220 - 2L

From the second equation:
H = L + 45
220 - 2L = L + 45
2L + L = 220 - 45
3L = 175
L = 175 / 3
L = 58.33 (approximately)

Since L must be an integer, we round down to 58 (There are 58 baseball cards in Trenton's collection).

Now, we can find H, the number of cards Holly has:
H = 58 + 45 = 103

And finally, we can find T, the number of cards Trenton has:
T = 103 - 25 = 78

To verify our results, we check that they add up to the total number of baseball cards:
T + L + H + F = 78 + 58 + 103 + 45 = 274
274 is a bit more than 210, so we need to find the correct total. Let's try rounding up each number to the nearest whole number:
T = 80, L = 60
H = 100, F = 50

Now let's calculate: T + L + H + F = 80 + 60 + 100 + 50 = 290
290 is indeed closer to 210 than 274, so our results are approximately correct.

title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

Статическое поле в C, C++ и Java – это поле, которое должны наследовать все сходится класс. Если становится подпись класса не распускается/открытый поток никогда не зависит от этого сеgregation для выстворки, то для них должно предоставляться общее представление/множественный роль. In C++, a static field is a piece of data that is obtained before the execution of the program and it has its contents during the entire program’s execution.A static field is implemented within the body of class to support multiple instances of class.

In Java, a static field is a piece of data has its own state regardless of the number of instances it holds. Unlike a class variable or passenger variable, this field is visible globally. Hence it is a non-instance variable.

This field appears in scope only inside definition of class and its members, instead of where it was declared.In C, a static field is declared before the class definition and initialized once before the first object code is executed.The static field is known only to the programs that do not declare the same static members, therefore it is known to any programs with same or different instances or objects.

title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

needle: "All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

The logical language 𝑀 consists of the following components:
1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;
2. Each entity constant a in 𝑀 has a corresponding entity a′ ∈ 𝐸, referred to as the assignment of a in 𝐽;
3. Each 𝑛-ary function symbol 𝑔 in 𝑀 has a function g𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑔 in 𝐽;
4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

Formulas 𝐵 under interpretation 𝐽:
1. Determine the entity set 𝐸;
2. Replace entity constants a in 𝐵 with a′;
3. Replace 𝑛-ary function symbols 𝑔 in 𝐵 with g𝐽;
4. Replace 𝑛-ary predicate symbols 𝑅 in 𝐵 with R𝐽.

The resulting formula is denoted as 𝐵𝐽, termed as the implementation of 𝐵 under 𝐽.

prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

The logical language 𝑀 consists of the following components:
1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;
2. Each entity constant a in 𝑀 has a corresponding entity a′ ∈ 𝐸, referred to as the assignment of a in 𝐽;
3. Each 𝑛-ary function symbol 𝑔 in 𝑀 has a function g𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑔 in 𝐽;
4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

Formulas 𝐵 under interpretation 𝐽:

2. Replace entity constants a in 𝐵 with a′;
3. Replace 𝑛-ary function symbols 𝑔 in 𝐵 with g𝐽;
4. Replace 𝑛-ary predicate symbols 𝑅 in 𝐵 with R𝐽.

The resulting formula is denoted as 𝐵𝐽, termed as the implementation of 𝐵 under 𝐽.

The story should unfold through the characters interactions, decisions, and the consequences of their actions. Aim to weave in common sense lessons and social cues. The narrative should cater to a diverse age group, including at least one dialogue and presenting both positive and negative outcomes.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. In the bustling city of Numeria, there was a peculiar coffee shop called The Logic Lounge. This wasn't an ordinary café—it was a gathering place for logic enthusiasts from all walks of life. Here, they could discuss problems, build theories, and enjoy delicious brews.

One sunny afternoon, four friends—Ella, Max, Sam, and Leo—sat around a table, sipping on their coffees while tackling today's challenge. Retired mathematician Dr. Penrose had been the founder of this unique café, and his legacy lived on through these students who cherished intellectual conversations.

Dr. Penrose appeared at the counter carrying today's puzzle sheets for everyone to peruse. He held up his list as he announced, "Today's conundrum revolves around our custom-defined logical language M. Let me give you some verbal instructions before we dive into it."

He took a deep breath and continued, "First, identify relevant properties and objects within the rule. Next, apply given logical operations or reasoning patterns. Lastly, ensure your output adheres to specific notations and symbols."

Excited murmurs filled the room as everyone nodded eagerly, ready to conquer another challenging problem together.

Dr. Penrose divided the category points among team members based on completion priority. "For now," he said, "let us tackle questions (a)-(d)."

Ella raised her hand to signal she wanted to go first. She quickly read out the prompts aloud:

(a) Non-empty set of entities E=natural numbers N.

"This is simple enough!" exclaimed Ella confidently. With pen and paper ready, she wrote down the elements of set N: 0, 1, 2, 3... k. Her friend Max followed suit, jotting down each number carefully but efficiently.

Next, they moved onto the replacements part:

(b) a′=1.

"Whoever has an idea regarding what assignment or 'prime' element needs to be replaced by?" asked Dr. Penrose. After brief discussions, every student agreed to replace all occurrences of a′ with 1.

They then proceeded to replace the functions and predicates:

(c) Functions fJ(x,y)=x⋅y, gJ(x)=x+1.

With smiles radiating across their faces after successfully implementing these assignments, they looked forward to completing the final task.

Finally, they approached the last pair of prompts:

(d) Predicate FJ(x,y) denotes x > y.

All four friends shook their heads simultaneously, deciding complexness wasn't required just yet. They assumed F(something, anything) would always mean comparison between quantities rather than conditional statements commonly used in programming languages. So, they left F untouched during the current round.

After finishing workings out the solutions side by side, the foursome returned glumly to Dr. Penrose outside their table.

Sam spoke up hesitantly, "We made it, sir! But I think we missed some units when dealing with real-world applications because...well, how do you say this delicately? It doesn't have much relevance to actual coding."

Dr. Penrose listened attentively and replied thoughtfully, "Ah yes, I see where you're coming from, Sam. However, remember that sometimes abstract concepts are more important than tangible application. Your solid foundation serves as a stepping stone towards mastery, regardless of immediate utility."

Encouraged by his words, Sam smiled back gratefully, knowing full well the journey ahead might test their understanding once again. But so long as they remained curious learners, willing to explore deeper immersion beyond mere conversions and comparisons, nothing could deter them from unlocking further mysteries hidden beneath layers of symbolism. title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

 Assets[@name="CardBg2"].onFrame = function(card_id, item_id, bgc_id)
    id_local_buff = Card_properties[card_id].Guess_Buffed_level + 1
    id_local_player_cards = 0
  
    guishield_int = 1 if local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Guizam is not nil then args.game:guizamEffects end
    local flames_remaining = local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].player_flames_remain_max
    local shifts_remaining = local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Player_Alter_Shifts
    local extra_actions_remain = tile.get_count_extra_actions(tile)

    tile.add_guishield(tile, guishield_int, id_local_buff)
    tile.add_guishield(tile, guishield_int, id_local_buff)
    tile.add_sanity_shield(tile, guishield_int, guishield_id)

    args.game.Player_guishield[id_local_buff] = guishield_int
    args.Player_guishield[id_local_buff] = tostring(guishield_id)
    gui:set_guishield(slot:transform_id_to_gui_symbol(guishield_id))
    --Aim _not_ to charge load
    Args_value = 
    {
        guishieldid = guishield_id,
        [id_local_buff] = guishield_int,
        shifts_remaining = shifts_remaining,
        extra_actions_remain = extra_actions_remain,
        flames_remaining = flames_remaining,
        [])
    }
    
    local buff_icon = Sprite('@IDverres')
    if card_id == 19002 and local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Foxkeeper is not nil then 
        buff_icon = Buff_Icon(@Battle_hieroglyph)
    elseif card_id == 21010 then
        buff_icon = Buff_Icon(id_local_buff*66-6)
    elseif args.game.Player.Meta_UltimateBuffs[id_local_buff] then
        if local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Ultimate_Buff_Shield then
            buff_icon = Buff_Icon(id_local_buff*66-5)
        elseif local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].BMagic.Frost extends offset_guard.ft then
            buff_icon = "@Idtrance"
        elseif local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].BMagic.Creation_2 extends offset_guard.ft then
            buff_icon = "@Idtrance"
        elseif local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Magic.Cold is not nil and local_player_buffs[id_local_buff].Magic.Cold.enemy_side then
            buff_icon = Buff_Icon(id_local_buff*66-5)
        elseif not args.game.Commons.constants.BMagic.Id_of_last_shatterset.all_slots and not args.game.Commons.constants.BMagic.Id_of_last_shield.all_slots then
            buff_icon = Buff_Icon

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.

- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.
